title: What is Blazor? (C# in the Browser!)
simplifierConcept:
Imagine building a website:

OLD WAY:
• HTML for structure
• CSS for styling
• JavaScript for interactivity
• C# on server (backend only)

BLAZOR WAY:
• HTML for structure
• CSS for styling
• C# for interactivity! (No JavaScript required!)
• C# everywhere - frontend AND backend!

Blazor = Write interactive web UIs using C# instead of JavaScript!

Think of it like:
• React/Vue/Angular = JavaScript frameworks
• Blazor = C# framework (same power, different language!)

Blazor lets you:
✅ Use C# skills for web development
✅ Share code between client and server
✅ Build SPAs (Single Page Applications)
✅ Rich interactivity without JavaScript
✅ Component-based architecture

Two main hosting models:
1. Blazor Server - C# runs on server, UI updates over SignalR
2. Blazor WebAssembly - C# runs IN BROWSER via WebAssembly
3. Blazor Auto (.NET 8) - Best of both!

Think: Blazor = 'Build modern web apps with C#, not JavaScript!'

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Blazor components use .razor extension. Mix HTML markup with C# code. Top part = markup, @code block = C# logic.
@ symbol in markup accesses C# variables/expressions. @currentCount displays the value. @DateTime.Now.Year shows current year.
Event binding with @. @onclick for clicks, @onchange for input changes. Binds to C# methods, not JavaScript!
Contains C# logic for component. Define fields, properties, methods here. Private by default. This is your component's brain!

challenge.instructions:
Create your first Blazor component!

1. Create a 'Greeting' component structure:
   - Title: "Welcome to Blazor!"
   - Display current year using @DateTime.Now.Year
   - Input field for user's name
   - Button "Greet Me"
   - When clicked, display "Hello, [name]! Welcome to Blazor!"

2. Component should have:
   - HTML markup section
   - @code block with:
     - string name field
     - string greeting field
     - GreetUser() method that sets greeting

3. Print the complete component structure

This demonstrates Blazor's syntax and interactivity!
challenge.hint: @bind for two-way binding on input. @onclick for button click. Use string interpolation in C# method. @if for conditional rendering. All C# code goes in @code block!
commonStickingPoints: Forgetting @ symbol: In markup, use @ to access C# variables! Just 'currentCount' won't work, need '@currentCount'. @ tells Blazor 'this is C#!'
JavaScript thinking: Don't add .js files or write JavaScript! Blazor uses C# for everything. @onclick calls C# methods, not JS functions.
Quotes in @onclick: Use @onclick="MethodName" (no parentheses unless passing parameters). For lambda: @onclick="() => count++" with quotes around entire expression.
Component naming: Component files must start with uppercase letter! Counter.razor (correct), counter.razor (wrong). This is C# convention.
